361:
B. He was charged with perjury.

Lying under oath is a serious offense and is considered perjury. Perjury is the act of lying or making verifiably false statements on a material matter under oath or affirmation in a court of law or in any of various sworn statements in writing. A person who commits perjury can be charged, convicted, and punished with fines and/or imprisonment. This consequence serves as a deterrent to discourage witnesses from lying and to maintain the integrity of the legal system. Therefore, if a witness lies under oath, the effect is that they will be charged with perjury.

374:
B. It was illegible.

The legibility of a note is a direct and primary factor that influences whether it will be read and understood. If the note was illegible, it would prevent you from comprehending its content, ultimately leading to its dismissal. Therefore, the legibility of the note is the most probable cause for you discarding it.
